docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: AT THE FAIRVIEW LAKE Y.M.C.A. camp near the Delaware Water Gap in rural New Jersey, children come from the New York suburbs for a few weeks of fresh air and exercise. They rise early to swim, ride horses, learn archery and play soccer and softball. The camp is many miles from any industry, and there might seem no healthier place for youths to spend a summer.

headline.main: On Ill Health and Air Pollution

byline.original: By Alice Bredin; Alice Bredin is a freelance journalist who writes about health issues

docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: ''What do you do about the gas?'' has become the most frequent response to current dietary advice to eat more fruits and vegetables, beans and peas, bran and whole grains. Indeed, in this high-fiber era, flatulence may have supplanted excess stomach acid as America's primary digestive complaint and concern.

docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: Two months after an experimental AIDS drug was unveiled here with fanfare and nationalistic triumph, many Africans have voiced high hopes that it might offer relief from the devastating epidemic, and patients from neighboring countries and even the United States have flocked here in search of treatment.

headline.main: In Kenya, a New AIDS Drug Gets Mired in Politics and Financial Disputes

byline.original: By JANE PERLEZ, Special to The New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: AMERICA'S obsession with dieting is having a severe impact on children, a House subcommittee was told last week in hearings addressing the safety of nonprescription diet pills.

headline.main: Children Are Focus Of Diet-Pill Issue
